Timely intervention can help prevent complications such as prolonged illness, persistent deformity or functional impairment within these vulnerable patients where prompt diagnosis coupled with thorough interdisciplinary team work remains crucial towards ensuring positive clinical outcomes.

Case Report 2  A 42-year-old male presented with sudden onset left-sided focal seizures which began earlier that day. Prior to seeking medical attention, he experienced two episodes lasting approximately 3-5 minutes each. These episodes were characterized by abnormal movements of his left arm and leg, accompanied by a marked disorientation afterwards. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he exhibited a tonic-clonic seizure involving his entire left side, including the face and upper and lower limbs.  The patient reported experiencing occasional headaches for several weeks prior to presentation; however, during the past five days, he had been enduring an intense throbbing headache localized to his right temple accompanied by severe light sensitivity and eye discomfort. Nonetheless, he vehemently denied any subjective complaints of fever or experiencing recent head trauma.  Upon physical examination upon arrival at the hospital, vital signs were within normal limits for his age. Neurological examination revealed no abnormalities except for minimal weakness on his left side following the seizure activity that resolved quickly thereafter.  The patient's past medical history was remarkable for hypertension managed with an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). He had not received any changes in medication regimen recently nor initiation of any new therapies.  Further diagnostic investigations were initiated promptly. Laboratory analysis demonstrated unremarkable complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels among others. Lumbar puncture was performed and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed no significant abnormalities including white blood cell count or glucose concentration.  Considering clinical features suggestive of focal seizures originating from the right hemisphere accompanied by recent-onset headaches associated with photophobia and painful eyes without any obvious precipitating event or evidence of infection/inflammatory process on initial evaluation prompted further investigations regarding an underlying etiology.   Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain scan was subsequently performed which displayed a small chronic ischemic lesion within the right cerebral hemisphere, consistent with a previous embolic event.  Based on the clinical presentation and radiological findings, a likely diagnosis of embolic stroke was made. The patient was started on appropriate secondary prevention measures including antiplatelet therapy in coordination with stroke specialists. Furthermore, counsel regarding lifestyle modifications to control hypertension and reduce cardiovascular risk factors was provided.  During his hospital stay, the patient's neurologic status remained stable without further seizure activity. He was discharged home with scheduled follow-up appointments for neurology consultation to assess seizure control and to develop an individualized plan for long-term seizure management.  In conclusion, this case highlights an unusual presentation of embolic stroke characterized by new-onset focal seizures accompanied by recent-onset headache associated with photophobia and painful eyes. Early recognition of atypical symptoms such as these is crucial for prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of patients presenting with similar clinical features Case Report 3  A 28-year-old female presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset left-sided focal seizures. She reported experiencing two episodes earlier that day, each lasting approximately 2-3 minutes, characterized by abnormal movements of her left arm and leg. These episodes were followed by a period of confusion and disorientation. On arrival at the hospital, she had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure involving her left side, including the face and upper and lower limbs.  The patient complained of persistent global headaches for the past five days. The headache was described as dull in nature, accompanied by sensitivity to light (photophobia) and eye discomfort. She denied any history of fever, nausea, vomiting or recent head trauma.  Upon examination upon admission, vital signs were stable within normal limits for her age. Neurological examination revealed no significant abnormalities except for a mild weakness on her left side following the seizure activity.  The patient's medical history was unremarkable with no chronic medical conditions or use of medications.  Initial laboratory investigations including complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP) levels were all within normal range. Lumbar puncture was performed with cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing no notable abnormalities such as elevated white blood cell count or glucose concentration.  Given the presence of new-onset focal seizures originating from the left hemisphere combined with recent-onset headaches associated with photophobia and painful eyes without any identifiable precipitating factors or evidence of infection/inflammation on initial evaluation prompted further investigations to establish an underlying cause.  Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the brain revealed a well-defined mass lesion within the left temporal lobe consistent with a low-grade glioma. Further consultation was sought from neurosurgeons who recommended surgical resection as definitive treatment for this tumor type.  While waiting for surgery scheduling, antiepileptic medications were initiated to control seizure activity. The patient also received counseling on the upcoming surgical procedure and possible long-term effects of the tumor.  In conclusion, this case represents an atypical presentation of a low-grade glioma in a young patient characterized by new-onset focal seizures, along with associated headaches, photophobia and painful eyes. Early recognition and further investigation are crucial for accurate diagnosis and timely intervention to ensure optimal clinical outcomes for patients presenting with similar clinical features. Neurosurgical intervention combined with appropriate antiepileptic management is vital in providing effective treatment for such cases.  The patient was discharged from the hospital with close follow-up appointments scheduled to monitor seizure control, plan for surgery, provide necessary education about the disease process and postoperative care, as well as offer psychological support during this challenging time.

Title: A 52-year-old man with HIV/AIDS and Progressive Respiratory Symptoms  Abstract: We present the case of a 52-year-old man with a history of HIV/AIDS for 9 years who presented with progressive respiratory symptoms, despite being on antiretroviral therapy (ART). The patient experienced breathlessness on exertion and fatigue over a period of two years, although he denied any cough, chest pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or orthopnea. His medical history was significant for well-controlled hypertension and dyslipidemia. Furthermore, the patient had been diagnosed with bilateral pulmonary emboli five years ago and had been receiving warfarin ever since. This report underscores the importance of considering both common and rare etiologies in patients living with HIV/AIDS.  Case Presentation:  A 52-year-old man presented to our clinic complaining of increasing breathlessness on exertion and persistent fatigue over the past two years. He denied any associated cough, chest pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or orthopnea. The patient mentioned having a chronic medical condition known as Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (HIV/AIDS), which had been diagnosed nine years earlier.  The patient's past medical history included well-managed hypertension managed on enalapril (10 mg once daily) and hydrochlorothiazide (12.5 mg once daily). Additionally, he had dyslipidemia controlled by atorvastatin (40 mg once daily).  Of note, a detailed review revealed that five years ago during an unrelated hospitalization for pneumonia at another facility; he was incidentally found to have bilateral pulmonary emboli. Treatment was initiated based on anticoagulation principles using warfarin therapy at an appropriate International Normalized Ratio target range between 2-3.  Besides his comorbidities requiring chronic pharmacotherapy described above; he had been on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) since the time of his HIV diagnosis. His HAART regimen consisted of a fixed-dose combination tablet of emtricitabine 200 mg/tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 300 mg once daily in combination with the non-nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor efavirenz 600 mg at bedtime.  Physical examination revealed a well-nourished man in no acute distress. Vital signs demonstrated a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at ambient air measured by pulse oximetry was within the normal limit at 98%.  Spirometry results were suggestive of moderate restrictive impairment, displaying an FEV1/FVC ratio at approximately 67% (predicted). There were no significant abnormalities detected on auscultation over both lung fields. Cardiac examination was unremarkable without audible murmurs or extra heart sounds.  Given the patient's recent history of bilateral pulmonary emboli and his persistent respiratory symptoms despite being on ART, further investigations were warranted to determine potential etiologies which could contribute to his symptoms.  His laboratory results were notable for stable CD4 counts above 500 cells/mm³ over follow-up appointments throughout previous years. HIV viral loads had been consistently undetectable except for one spike reported as "low-level viremia" nine months ago.  Conclusion:  We present a case emphasizing the importance of considering various causes when evaluating patients presenting with progressive respiratory symptoms while living with HIV/AIDS. This patient's clinical history includes prior pulmonary emboli and ongoing warfarin therapy related to it; yet, additional investigations are necessary to delineate other potential contributors to his chronic dyspnea and fatigue despite adequate control measures for underlying conditions such as hypertension and dyslipidemia.

Mr. John Smith, a 58-year-old male patient, arrives at the outpatient department of Cardiology with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath. He works as a truck driver and has been experiencing these symptoms for the past six months.   According to Mr. Smith's medical history, he was completely asymptomatic prior to the onset of his symptoms. Initially, he noticed occasional episodes of chest pain that gradually became more frequent and intense over time. The pain is described as dull and localized in nature, predominantly located on the left side of his chest.  There are no specific aggravating or relieving factors identified by Mr. Smith; however, physical activities like walking uphill or carrying heavy objects seem to exacerbate his symptoms further. He recalls feeling a sense of tightness in his chest during these activities.  In addition to the chest pain, Mr. Smith also reports experiencing shortness of breath for the past two months. He notices it mostly when climbing stairs or engaging in any form of exertion that requires increased oxygen demand.  Upon further inquiry about associated symptoms, Mr. Smith reveals experiencing occasional lightheadedness when he stands up quickly from a sitting or supine position but not associated with any loss of consciousness.  Regarding past medical history, Mr. Smith mentions having been diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago which has been managed fairly well with medication (Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme Inhibitor). No other major health issues have been documented so far.  Further examination reveals no facial asymmetry or abnormalities; however, an additional symptom manifests itself during this discussion: occasional episodes numbness on the left side from head down following nerve path towards jawline lasting few minutes usually after prolonged exposure change cold/warm environment "wind feeling".  In conclusion: Mr. John Smith is a 58-year-old male truck driver presenting at Cardiology outpatient department with complaints suggestive angina pectoris characterized by progressively worsening chest pain and associated shortness of breath. His clinical findings indicate a possible stable angina with stable asymtomatic hypertension. He also mentions episodes of lightheadedness on sudden positional changes and numbnes on the left side of his head.  Further investigations, including an ECG and stress test, will be required to confirm the diagnosis as well as evaluate the severity and extent of coronary artery disease. Additionally, appropriate management strategies such as lifestyle modifications, medication adjustment or addition for hypertension control, and possible anti-anginal medications will be discussed with Mr. Smith during subsequent visits to manage his symptomatology effectively. Further evaluation of Mr. John Smith's medical history and physical examination reveals additional symptoms that require attention. Upon further inquiry, Mr. Smith reports occasional palpitations accompanied by a sense of "racing heart" lasting for a few minutes and subsiding on its own. These episodes occur once or twice a week but are unrelated to any specific triggers or activities.  Mr. Smith also mentions intermittent episodes of mild dizziness, characterized by a sensation of lightheadedness and feeling off-balance particularly when he turns his head quickly or changes positions abruptly.  His past medical history includes an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg three years ago, for which he was treated with anticoagulant therapy for six months. No ongoing clotting disorders are reported.  Physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities apart from mild obesity and elevated blood pressure readings ranging between 140/90 mmHg to 160/100 mmHg across multiple visits.  Given the presence of these additional symptoms and Mr. Smith's medical history, the possibility of cardiac arrhythmias is raised as a potential contributing factor to his presenting complaints.  Further investigations are warranted to evaluate the suspected arrhythmias in conjunction with his existing coronary artery disease diagnosis:  1. Complete blood count (CBC): To assess for any underlying anemia or infection. 2. Electrocardiogram (ECG): To identify any abnormal cardiac electrical activity. 3. Holter monitor: A portable device worn by the patient over 24-48 hours that records continuous ECG data to capture any arrhythmic events during daily activities. 4. Echocardiography: An ultrasound scan used to assess cardiac function, identify structural abnormalities, and estimate ejection fraction. 5.Cardiac stress test: To evaluate exercise tolerance levels, detect ischemia during physical exertion if present 6.Doppler ultrasound study for deep venous system lower limbs 7. 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM): To evaluate blood pressure patterns over a 24-hour period, including during sleep and waking hours.  Based on the findings from these investigations, appropriate treatment strategies will be implemented. This can range from lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise, weight reduction, and dietary changes to pharmacological interventions like antiarrhythmic drugs or anticoagulation therapy if indicated.  Further follow-up visits will be scheduled to assess treatment efficacy, monitor cardiac function, and address any concerns or new symptoms that may arise during Mr. Smith's course of management.  In conclusion: Mr. John Smith's clinical manifestations suggest a possible underlying arrhythmia in addition to his stable angina. Further diagnostic testing has been recommended to confirm this suspicion and identify the specific type of arrhythmia involved. Subsequent treatment interventions will aim at managing both conditions concurrently while optimizing his blood pressure control as well as assessing for any recurrence or complications related to DVT history with the aid of Doppler ultrasound study for deep venous system lower limbs.  Continued monitoring followed by ongoing patient education regarding symptom recognition is necessary to ensure comprehensive care delivery and maximize Mr. Smith's overall cardiovascular health outcomes in line with evidence-based guidelines.

Patient 35 year old Caucasian male father of one presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain and swelling in the scrotum. The patient reported a dull, aching pain in his lower abdomen and groin region, accompanied by bilateral scrotal swelling and a sensation of heaviness. The left-sided scrotal swelling had been present for approximately four years, while the right-sided swelling had developed over the past two years.   The patient denied any relevant past medical history or any significant personal or family history that could be pertinent to establish a provisional diagnosis. He further mentioned that he had not experienced any recent trauma or injury to his genital area.  Upon examination, the patient's vital signs were stable with no abnormalities observed in cardiovascular function, respiratory status, nor neurological examination findings.  During local examination of the genital area, there was noticeable bilateral swelling involving both hemiscrota; however, it appeared more prominent on the left side compared to the right side. Further evaluation revealed no discoloration or skin changes associated with either testicle or surrounding structures. The skin was intact without any palpable nodules or irregularities.   In order to arrive at an accurate diagnosis and establish appropriate management strategies for this patient, additional investigations were ordered. Blood workup included routine laboratory tests such as complete blood count (CBC), liver enzyme levels (LFTs), kidney function tests (KFTs), and tumor markers such as alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). All routine blood test results fell within normal ranges.  To visualize potential structural anomalies within the abdominal and pelvic regions that may contribute to the presenting symptoms and findings on physical examination, imaging studies such as ultrasound scans were performed. Ultrasound revealed bilateral enlargement of both testicles; however, there were no evident masses detected during this initial investigation.  Due to persistent symptoms along with concerning physical exam findings warranting further evaluation, a consultation with a urologist was requested for the patient. The urologist planned to pursue additional investigations to reach a final diagnosis. These would include a scrotal ultrasound, which provides more detailed visualization of the testicles and surrounding structures.  The provisionally suspected diagnosis included various etiologies ranging from testicular malignancy such as seminoma or non-seminoma germ cell tumors, hydrocele and varicoceles, among others. However, at this stage of evaluation, no definitive conclusions could be made regarding the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms.  In conclusion, this case describes a 35-year-old male presenting with chronic abdominal pain accompanied by bilateral scrotal swelling and heaviness. With no significant past medical history or family background that could shed light on potential diagnoses, further investigations were initiated including blood tests and ultrasound scans. The suspected differential diagnoses involve conditions such as malignancies (particularly testicular tumors), hydroceles and varicoceles. Collaboration with a urology specialist was warranted to guide subsequent investigation and management plans for this patient's condition. Further studies are required to establish an accurate diagnosis in order to implement appropriate treatment strategies tailored to this individual's needs. Following the initial evaluation and consultation with the urologist, additional investigations were carried out as part of the diagnostic workup for our patient.  A scrotal ultrasound was performed to provide a more detailed visualization of the testicles and surrounding structures. The ultrasound revealed bilateral enlargement of both testicles, confirming the previous findings. However, no masses or abnormalities were detected within the testicular parenchyma or epididymis.  Given these inconclusive results, it became crucial to explore further in order to definitively diagnose and manage our patient's condition.  To determine if there were any underlying hormonal imbalances that could be contributing to his symptoms, hormone panel testing was conducted. The results showed normal levels of testosterone, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and prolactin. No hormonal abnormalities were identified that might explain his clinical presentation.  Since all non-invasive investigations failed to provide a conclusive diagnosis thus far, a decision was made to proceed with an exploratory surgical procedure known as a diagnostic laparoscopy. This minimally invasive technique would allow for direct visualization and assessment of intra-abdominal structures along with biopsy sampling if any suspicious lesions were encountered.  During the laparoscopic procedure, multiple small incisions were made in the abdominal wall through which specialized instruments including a camera were inserted. The surgeon meticulously examined various intraperitoneal organs including the liver, spleen, kidneys, bladder, and lymph nodes for any signs of pathology or abnormality.  Ultimately, two small nodules measuring approximately 0.5 cm in diameter each were discovered on one of the peritoneal surfaces just below where it attaches to the left inguinal canal—a site unaccounted for during prior evaluations due to its deep location within the abdomen. A biopsy was promptly performed on these nodules during surgery and sent for histopathological examination.  The post-operative recovery period was uneventful, with the patient being closely monitored for any signs of infection or complications. Once he had sufficiently healed, follow-up consultation was scheduled to discuss the biopsy results and establish a definitive diagnosis.  Histopathological analysis revealed that the nodules were consistent with metastatic seminoma—a type of testicular germ cell tumor that typically arises from malignant transformation within the testicles and subsequently spreads to distant sites through lymphatic or hematogenous routes.  Upon receiving this significant finding, an urgent multidisciplinary meeting comprising urologists, medical oncologists, pathologists, and radiologists was held to develop a comprehensive treatment plan tailored to our patient. The proposed management included surgical removal of both testicles (bilateral orchiectomy) followed by adjuvant chemotherapy targeting any potential occult micrometastases.  The devastating diagnosis left our patient understandably bewildered and apprehensive about the challenging journey ahead. Patient education sessions focusing on his specific condition were organized to address his concerns, explain treatment strategies in detail, outline possible side effects of therapy while reassuring him that prognosis for early-stage seminomas is generally favorable.  In conclusion, this case describes a 35-year-old male who initially presented with chronic abdominal pain along with bilateral scrotal swelling and heaviness. Despite multiple investigations indicating no abnormalities earlier on in his evaluation process—including normal ultrasound findings—a diagnostic laparoscopy eventually led to discovery of metastatic seminoma nodules within the peritoneal cavity. This rare presentation highlights the importance of persistence in clinical practice when faced with inconclusive results. Appropriate interdisciplinary collaboration allowed for prompt establishment of further diagnostic steps leading towards an eventual definitive diagnosis and subsequent development of a comprehensive management plan tailored specifically for our patient's unique circumstances.

Case 2: A 60-year-old female patient presented to our department with a two-week history of worsening headaches and intermittent right-sided weakness. The patient reported no significant head trauma but had noticed increasing difficulty with daily activities such as writing and buttoning clothes. Upon further questioning, the patient disclosed a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, both of which were well-controlled.  Physical examination revealed decreased strength in her right upper and lower extremities, with notable difficulty in gripping objects. Cranial CT scan was performed, revealing bilateral chronic subdural hematomas (CSDH), more prominent on the left side. The findings were consistent with the patient's symptoms.  In addition to her chronic medical conditions, the patient had also been experiencing occasional palpitations and shortness of breath during physical exertion in recent months. To assess her cardiovascular health prior to surgery, chest radiography and electrocardiogram (ECG) were performed. The chest radiograph showed mild cardiomegaly but no other abnormalities. The ECG demonstrated sinus rhythm with occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVCs).  Laboratory investigations included a comprehensive blood analysis to assess hematological parameters. Fortunately, all results fell within normal limits, ruling out any coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia that could complicate surgical management.  Given the symptomatology observed on examination along with supportive imaging findings showing bilateral CSDHs predominantly on the left side, neurosurgical intervention was necessary to evacuate these hematomas.  The patient was informed about the potential risks associated with surgery including bleeding or infection but decided to proceed due to persistent debilitating symptoms affecting her quality of life.  An interdisciplinary team consisting of neurosurgeons and anesthesiologists reviewed the case thoroughly before proceeding with surgery. A detailed discussion ensued regarding management strategies for perioperative hypertension control given that uncontrolled hypertension could increase bleeding risk during surgical manipulation within the cranium. It was decided to optimize the patient's blood pressure preoperatively and monitor it closely throughout the procedure.  On the day of surgery, the patient was brought to the operating room and positioned supine in a slightly elevated position. General anesthesia was induced followed by endotracheal intubation for airway protection during surgery. Intraoperative monitoring included arterial blood pressure, central venous pressure, end-tidal carbon dioxide, and oxygen saturation.  A left frontal burr hole craniotomy with evacuation of subdural hematomas under neuro-navigation guidance was performed successfully without any intraoperative complications. The surgical team ensured meticulous hemostasis before closing the incision site with absorbable sutures.  Postoperatively, neurological status monitoring in the intensive care unit (ICU) revealed gradual improvement of motor function in her right upper and lower extremities within 24 hours. Analgesic medications were provided as necessary to manage anticipated pain at both operative sites - her head and chest wall from incision discomfort caused by coughing post-intubation.  The patient remained stable throughout her hospital stay with continued improvement in muscle strength on daily examinations performed by nursing staff as part of postoperative care. Physical therapy interventions were initiated early to aid in functional recovery.  In conclusion, this case highlights the successful management of a 60-year-old female patient presenting with chronic subdural hematomas causing persistent headaches and limb weakness. Through interdisciplinary collaboration and individualized perioperative care planning tailored to her coexisting medical conditions, neurosurgical intervention led to significant improvement in symptoms and subsequent rehabilitation efforts aimed at optimizing her overall functional outcomes.

Case: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, osteoarthritis and previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery was referred to the oral medicine and oral surgery department at HILLTOP Hospital (Melbourne, Australia) due to persistent pain and discomfort localized in the left mandibular region. The patient reported experiencing difficulty in opening his mouth fully and constant tenderness while chewing.  Upon conducting an extraoral examination, it was noted that the patient had a slightly swollen left submandibular lymph node measuring approximately 1.5 cm in diameter. The lymph node exhibited firm consistency upon palpation.  During the intraoral examination, it was observed that the patient had poor oral hygiene with plaque accumulation on multiple teeth. In particular, attention was drawn to a gingival bleeding lesion with raised edges situated adjacent to the first molar (36). The lesion appeared ulcerated locally and had a class 2 mobility grade.  The medical history of this patient revealed he had been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus twenty years ago. He has been managing this condition with insulin injections as prescribed by his endocrinologist. Additionally, he has a long-standing history of hypertension for which he takes antihypertensive medications regularly. Osteoarthritis affects multiple joints throughout his body, causing chronic pain for which he takes over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs occasionally.  The most notable cardiovascular event in this patient's medical history is being treated for coronary artery disease via CABG surgery eight years ago at a different hospital facility after suffering from recurring angina symptoms despite optimal medical management. Since then, regular follow-up visits indicated satisfactory recovery post-surgery without any significant cardiac complications or additional interventions required.  Given his current presentation at HILLTOP Hospital's oral medicine department, further diagnostic tests were arranged for our patient including radiographic imaging such as panoramic radiograph and CBCT scan. Blood investigations were also ordered to assess his glycemic control and inflammatory markers.  The clinical findings, presence of swollen submandibular lymph nodes, along with the local ulcerated gingival lesion raised concerns for possible underlying pathology within the affected mandibular region. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a malignant neoplasm that commonly involves the lymph nodes and occasionally manifests in oral tissues causing non-healing ulcers, was considered as a differential diagnosis based on these findings.  To manage the patient's symptoms effectively while awaiting diagnostic confirmation, conservative measures were implemented. He was advised to maintain rigorous oral hygiene practices at home including comprehensive brushing twice daily along with flossing. Chlorhexidine mouthwash was prescribed to reduce plaque accumulation until further treatment options could be considered.  The patient progressed well with symptomatic relief during his follow-up visits at regular intervals scheduled every two weeks. In subsequent appointments, results from blood investigations showed relatively stable glycemic control without any significant abnormalities in other inflammatory markers.  Based on evolving clinical evidence combined with laboratory results received over a 6-week period from the initial presentation, appropriate multidisciplinary consultations were conducted between oral medicine specialists and an oncologist team specialized in hematological malignancies to reach a definitive diagnosis and explore management options tailored specifically for our patient's needs.  In conclusion, this case highlights the importance of identifying systemic conditions as contributing factors for intraoral manifestations. The complex medical history of our patient necessitates close collaboration between various healthcare disciplines while formulating an accurate diagnosis and establishing optimal treatment plans to improve overall outcomes for patients experiencing similar symptoms.

Case: A 42-year-old woman, gravida 4 para 4, presented with an increased size of breast lump. Her history revealed a diagnosis of left breast fibroadenoma measuring 2cm in diameter, made by her primary care physician five years ago. She had regular mammograms every two years at a community clinic and the fibroadenoma size remained stable during this period. However, she was referred to our institution in May 2021 due to the recent increase in the size of the breast lump noticed on self-examination.  The patient stated that she first noticed a small lump in her left breast about five years ago while performing her monthly self-breast examination. At that time, she sought medical attention from her primary care physician who ordered imaging studies to further evaluate the lump. The mammogram confirmed the presence of a solitary well-circumscribed mass consistent with fibroadenoma measuring approximately 2cm in diameter.  Due to its benign nature and stability over time, close surveillance was deemed appropriate for this patient considering her age and risk factors. Therefore, it was decided at that time to continue monitoring regularly without any intervention required or referral to a specialist.  Over the last five years since diagnosis, the patient underwent regular mammograms every two years as recommended by national guidelines for early detection of breast cancer in average-risk women. All follow-up mammograms showed no concerning changes regarding growth or appearance of the fibroadenoma.  However, earlier this month during routine self-breast examination which she performed on a monthly basis as advised by healthcare professionals; she observed an increase in size and firmness of the previously stable mass located within her left breast.  Concerned about these new findings, she followed up with another appointment with her primary care physician who promptly ordered repeat imaging studies including diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound evaluation. The results indicated significant enlargement of pre-existing fibroadenoma now measuring approximately 5cm in its maximum dimension.  In light of this concerning change, her primary care physician decided to refer the patient to our institution for further evaluation and management. The patient arrived at our clinic expressing worries regarding the recent growth of the breast lump, as well as new onset pain and discomfort associated with it.  Upon physical examination, a solitary, non-tender mass was palpated in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. No axillary lymphadenopathy or skin changes were noted.  Given the significant increase in size along with new associated symptoms such as pain and discomfort, additional investigations were indicated. It was planned to perform a core needle biopsy of the fibroadenoma under imaging guidance to verify its histopathological characteristics and rule out any potential malignant transformation.  Furthermore, bloodwork including complete blood count (CBC), liver function tests (LFTs), renal function tests (RFTs), serum tumor markers such as cancer antigen (CA) 15-3 and CA 27-29 levels were ordered to assess for any other concerning findings or underlying systemic pathologies that might contribute towards these changes.  To provide comprehensive care for this patient who is understandably anxious about recent developments, we aim to communicate effectively while addressing her concerns by explaining the rationale behind various investigations planned and ensuring a thorough evaluation of all possible differential diagnoses before confirming a treatment plan tailored specifically according to her needs.

Title: A 38-year-old Woman with Chronic Cough and Pleural Effusion  Introduction: Ms. K is a 38-year-old woman who presented to the clinic with a chronic cough and pleural effusion. She has a significant medical history of bronchiectasis and recurrent respiratory infections. Furthermore, she has been an active smoker for the past 20 years.  Presenting Complaint: Ms. K complained of a persistent, non-productive cough that had been present for three months. She also reported experiencing occasional night sweats, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 kilograms over the same period. Additionally, she noted occasional mild dyspnea on exertion.  Medical History: Ms. K had been diagnosed with bronchiectasis ten years ago after presenting with recurrent chest infections characterized by productive cough, purulent sputum, and hemoptysis. Her condition was managed conservatively through chest physiotherapy and appropriate antibiotic therapy during exacerbations. She was otherwise fit and had no other significant medical history or allergies to medications.  Clinical Findings:  Physical Examination: On examination, Ms. K appeared generally pale but not in any acute distress at rest. Vital signs were stable within normal limits: blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate 76 bpm, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min (without apparent distress), temperature98°F(36°C). Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung zone. No rales or rhonchi were audible in any lung fields bilaterally. There were no palpable lymph nodes on neck examination or hepatosplenomegaly noticed upon abdominal palpation. No clubbing of fingers or peripheral edema was appreciated.  Investigations:  Laboratory Findings: Complete blood count showed mild anemia (hemoglobin level of10 g/dL)  Radiographic Imaging:  A posterior-anterior chest radiograph revealed a moderate right-sided pleural effusion, confirmed by lateral decubitus chest X-ray. The right hemidiaphragm was obscured due to the effusion, and mediastinal shift was appreciated.  Diagnostic Procedures: To further evaluate the pleural effusion and rule out malignancy, a diagnostic thoracentesis was performed. Analysis of the pleural fluid revealed an exudative nature with elevated adenosine deaminase levels (greater than 40 U/L) and lymphocytic predominance.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation of chronic cough, weight loss, night sweats, dyspnea on exertion, unilateral pleural effusion with lymphocytic predominance and elevated adenosine deaminase levels in the pleural fluid analysis, a high index of suspicion for tuberculous pleurisy was considered.  Treatment Plan:  Considering the clinical findings suggestive of tuberculosis (TB), Ms. K was started on standard antituberculous therapy consisting of Isoniazid (H), Rifampicin (R), Pyrazinamide (Z), and Ethambutol (E) for an initial period of two months. Continuation phase treatment with HR regimen would then be continued for another four months. She was provided education regarding adherence to therapy as well as counseling on smoking cessation strategies.  Follow-up Plan: Ms. K is scheduled for regular follow-up visits every month to monitor her tuberculosis treatment response. During these visits, her symptoms will be assessed along with periodic laboratory investigations such as sputum testing or chest imaging studies if needed. Her progress in smoking cessation efforts will also be discussed during each visit.  Conclusion: This case highlights a middle-aged woman presenting with chronic cough and weight loss coupled with lung pathology suggestive of tuberculous pleurisy following years of bronchiectasis management. The prompt diagnosis initiation of appropriate antituberculous treatment, along with tailored follow-up plans, will be vital in ensuring Ms. K's successful recovery and improving her long-term respiratory health.

Title: A 52-year-old male presenting with persistent knee pain and limited mobility: A case study  Introduction: A 52-year-old male patient, Mr. John Smith, presented to the Orthopedic Department of Oakwood General Hospital (Springfield, USA). He complained of persistent pain and difficulty in flexing his right knee joint. No significant medical issues were previously reported for the patient. This clinical case aims to explore further into the origin of the symptoms and provide a comprehensive evaluation.  Clinical History: Mr. Smith reported prolonged discomfort and instability in his right knee joint for approximately eight months. The symptoms progressively worsened over time, leading him to seek medical assistance at our hospital. During assessment interviews, Mr. Smith denied any direct trauma or involvement in strenuous physical activities that could have attributed to his condition.  Past Medical History: No pertinent details regarding past surgeries or injuries were obtained during Mr. Smith's assessment process.  Examination Findings: Physical examination revealed localized tenderness on palpation over the medial aspect of his right knee joint and slight effusion without redness or warmth upon inspection. Passive range-of-motion was determined as limited flexion of approximately 90 degrees due to intense pain experienced by Mr. Smith when attempting deep flexion.  Radiological Evaluation: To evaluate the underlying cause accurately, radiographic imaging was performed on Mr. Smith's right knee joint as part of routine diagnostic procedures deemed necessary by our orthopedic team.  Radiographic findings revealed mild osteoarthritic changes characterized by narrowing of the medial compartment space with marginal osteophyte formation seen along tibiofemoral articulation surfaces consistent with degenerative arthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade II). No signs of bony erosions or fractures were observed within the imaging examination limits.  Risk Factors Assessment:  During thorough patient history analysis, no significant risk factors related to chronic joints diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis or gout, or previous traumatic injuries were identified. Mr. Smith denied any smoking or excessive alcohol consumption.  Treatment Plan: Based on the clinical presentation, physical examination findings, and radiographic evidence suggesting degenerative knee arthritis (localized to the medial compartment), a comprehensive treatment plan was devised for Mr. Smith.  1. Medications: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) were prescribed to alleviate pain and reduce inflammation in the affected joint. 2. Physical Therapy: Mr. Smith was recommended to undergo targeted physical therapy sessions focusing on therapeutic exercises, proprioception training, and gait training. 3. Lifestyle Modifications: The patient was advised to maintain a healthy body weight by incorporating regular exercise into his routine, avoiding strenuous activities that exacerbate knee pain. 4. Intra-articular Corticosteroid Injection: In cases where conservative measures fail to provide adequate relief from symptoms, consideration would be given for an intra-articular corticosteroid injection.  Follow-up Strategy: Mr. Smith's progress will be monitored through follow-up appointments at regular intervals of six weeks initially and then as per clinical necessity thereafter for further evaluation of his condition and adjustment of treatment strategies if needed.  Conclusion: This case study highlights the diagnostic assessment process of a 52-year-old male presenting with persistent knee pain and limited mobility attributed to osteoarthritis affecting the medial compartment of his right knee joint. An individualized treatment plan involving conservative management techniques has been initiated with close monitoring required for assessing response to therapy along with potential adjustments as required by patient needs during follow-up visits in our Orthopedic Department at Oakwood General Hospital in Springfield, USA

Clinical Case: A 33-year-old woman presented to the dental clinic complaining of dissatisfaction with her smile due to excessive gingival display. There were no notable medical or family history, and the patient reported no contraindications for any proposed treatment. On clinical evaluation, an extraoral examination revealed symmetric facial features with normal lip competence. Intraorally, a sufficient amount of attached gingiva was observed, supporting a diagnosis of "gummy smile." However, upon smiling, the patient displayed visible teeth from the maxillary right first molar to maxillary left first premolar with 6-7 mm of gingival exposure. The maxillary anterior teeth exhibited normal anatomic proportions.  Patient History: Ms. S is a non-smoking 33-year-old female who presented seeking improvement in the aesthetics of her smile. Her medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications or have any known allergies. She maintains good oral hygiene practices, including regular brushing twice daily and flossing once daily.  Clinical Examination: Extraoral examination demonstrated facial symmetry at rest without any evidence of lip incompetency or abnormal muscle movements affecting her dento-facial esthetics.  Intraoral examination revealed excellent oral health status with minimal plaque accumulation and healthy periodontal tissues throughout all areas examined. The attached gingiva was within normal limits on both buccal and lingual aspects in relation to all teeth surveyed in both arches.  Upon requesting Ms.S to perform a full smile for evaluation purposes, it was observed that there was significant visualization of gum tissue involving from the right first molar up until the left first premolar position in her upper jaw.  The dimensional evaluation indicated approximately 6-7 mm vertical space from the tip of incisal edges up until where gums emerged indicating an excess gingival display while smiling conditionally categorized under "gummy smile."  Differential Diagnosis: 1) Excessive Gingival Display (Gummy Smile) 2) Vertical Maxillary Excess 3) Hyperactive Upper Lip  Treatment Plan: The treatment plan for Ms. S involves coordinating interdisciplinary care with the aesthetic dental team consisting of a periodontist, orthodontist, and oral surgeon. The following procedures were discussed with the patient:  1) Periodontal Crown Lengthening: To address the excessive gingival display, surgical crown lengthening will be performed to reveal more tooth structure. This procedure aims to recontour the gum line, reducing vertical dimensions and harmonizing it with her smile.  2) Orthodontic Treatment: Following periodontal crown lengthening, orthodontic treatment will be initiated to optimize tooth position and alignment within the arches.  3) Oral Surgery Consultation: An oral surgery consultation will be arranged at a later stage if deemed necessary after completion of crown lengthening and orthodontic interventions. This phase would involve further evaluation for possible skeletal discrepancies or lip-related issues such as hyperactivity or muscle tension that might contribute to an unfavorable esthetic outcome.  4) Comprehensive Maintenance Care: Postoperative care instructions emphasizing thorough plaque control techniques, regular dental visits every six months for monitoring healing progress, maintaining periodontal health along with any additional restorative requirements may be incorporated into Ms.S's overall comprehensive maintenance plan.  Conclusion: In conclusion, Ms. S presents as a 33-year-old female seeking improvement in her smile aesthetics due to excessive gingival display during smiling. Based on clinical examination findings and diagnostic evaluation methods conducted by our interdisciplinary team consisting of a periodontist, orthodontist, and oral surgeon specialists; a comprehensive treatment plan involving surgical crown lengthening followed by orthodontic intervention seems most appropriate in addressing her concerns while optimizing functional stability for long-term success.

A 45-year-old female with a history of diabetes presented with sudden-onset, severe right lower abdominal pain, radiating to the back and associated with vomiting and fever. She denied any history of urinary symptoms or recent upper respiratory tract infections. The patient denied any contact with individuals who had tested positive for COVID-19. On examination, she appeared uncomfortable and in moderate distress but was fully alert and oriented. Her vital signs revealed a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate of 110 beats per minute, blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.  Abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower quadrant along with involuntary guarding and rebound tenderness localized to McBurney's point. Bowel sounds were audible but slightly diminished compared to normal. Rectal examination was normal without any palpable masses or melena.  Laboratory investigations showed an elevated white blood cell count of 17,000 cells/mm³ (reference range: 4,000-11,000 cells/mm³) with a predominance of neutrophils on differential count. Hemoglobin levels were within normal limits at 13 g/dL (reference range:12-15 g/dL). Serum electrolytes were within normal ranges.  Based on the clinical presentation and physical findings consistent with acute appendicitis, the patient underwent urgent surgical consultation for further management. Imaging studies such as ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) scan were considered but delayed due to limited availability during off-hours at the hospital.  Given her ongoing symptoms and clinical deterioration over time along with evidence of systemic inflammation indicated by fever and elevated white blood cell count - as well as classic signs on physical examination - an immediate exploratory laparotomy was performed by the surgical team without preoperative imaging.  Intraoperatively it was noted that there were fecaliths obstructing the lumen of the appendix leading to inflammation and subsequent perforation of the appendix. An appendectomy was completed, and intra-abdominal lavage with normal saline was performed followed by thorough irrigation with antibiotics.  Postoperatively, the patient was started on intravenous antibiotics consisting of a combination of ceftriaxone and metronidazole for coverage against aerobic gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes. Pain management was achieved using intravenous opioids as needed, along with antiemetics for symptomatic relief. The patient was kept nil per oral initially to facilitate recovery from intestinal manipulation but gradually advanced to a clear liquid diet as tolerated.  During her hospital stay, she demonstrated sustained clinical improvement with resolution of fever, reduction in abdominal pain, and return of normal bowel function. The surgical wound remained clean without any signs of infection or dehiscence.  The patient's blood cultures obtained on admission remained negative after 48 hours. Repeat laboratory investigations showed a reducing trend in her total white cell count that had normalized within three days post-operatively.  Given the uncomplicated postoperative course and return to baseline condition without complications observed during hospitalization, she was discharged home on postoperative day four with oral antibiotics (amoxicillin-clavulanate) for one week along with clear instructions for follow-up at the surgical clinic in two weeks' time to ensure appropriate wound healing monitoring.  In summary, based on clinical presentation consistent with acute appendicitis including right lower quadrant pain associated with fever and leukocytosis - this patient underwent an emergency surgical intervention resulting in successful appendectomy without any immediate complications observed during hospitalization or subsequent follow-up visits at our tertiary care facility.

Ms. Y, a 65-year-old retired teacher, presented to the clinic with complaints of exertional dyspnea and a chronic ulcerated wound on her right foot that had been persistently bleeding on contact for the past four months. Ms. Y reported that her symptoms began gradually about four months ago and were initially characterized by pain and swelling in her right foot. The swelling and tenderness progressed over time, accompanied by skin peeling and the development of a budding wound.  Ms. Y sought medical attention at a local clinic in her hometown, located in the rural outskirts of Gwalior (Central India), where she was initiated on antibiotic therapy with cloxacillin at a daily dose of 2 grams for two months. Unfortunately, this treatment regimen did not bring any improvement to her condition.  During the initial evaluation at our clinic, Ms. Y reported mild shortness of breath upon performing daily activities such as walking up stairs or carrying groceries, indicating exertional dyspnea. She mentioned experiencing fatigue after minimal activity as well.  On further examination of Ms. Y's right foot, we observed an ulcerated wound measuring approximately 4 cm x 4 cm situated on the plantar aspect near the base of her toes. The wound appeared deep with irregular edges and exhibited signs of active bleeding upon touch.  In addition to her respiratory symptoms and the chronic ulceration on her foot, Ms.Y also revealed being diabetic for over ten years but having experienced controlled blood glucose levels through regular medication intake prescribed by primary care physicians from neighboring clinics.  Considering both Ms.Y's diabetic history as well as persistent ulceration despite prior antibiotic treatment, we suspected that she might be suffering from a diabetic foot infection with potentially deeper tissue involvement beyond what was visible externally.  To validate this hypothesis further, an arterial Doppler study was ordered to evaluate blood flow to both legs comprehensively while ruling out peripheral artery disease exacerbating poor wound healing in this case. A complete blood count was also assessed to determine any leukocytosis, suggesting a systemic inflammatory response.  Simultaneously, appropriate wound care measures were initiated for Ms.Y's right foot ulceration. This included gentle cleansing with normal saline and application of moist sterile dressings, with instructions provided for adequate off-loading through the use of pressure-relieving footwear.  Given the complexity of her case and the need for collaborative management between multiple specialties, a multidisciplinary team consisting of a diabetologist, vascular surgeon, wound care specialist, and an infectious disease expert was constituted to devise an integrated treatment plan for Ms.Y.  After obtaining arterial Doppler study results indicating no significant arterial compromise in both legs and ruling out peripheral artery disease as a contributing factor to non-healing wounds in this scenario, our suspicion towards deeper infectious involvement within soft tissues increased. To confirm our diagnosis and guide appropriate antibiotic therapy selection based on bacterial sensitivity results from deep tissue samples when required later on if deemed necessary accordingly at expert discretion; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was scheduled to assess any fascial plane involvement or abscess formation below the visible ulcerations as warranted clinically.  A comprehensive management strategy addressing both systemic factors such as glycemic control optimization alongside specialized local wound care techniques aimed towards healing promotion will be Case Study: A 35-year-old Male with Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction  Introduction: A 35-year-old male presented to the orofacial pain and temporomandibular dysfunction unit of the university medical dental clinic with a persistent complaint of limited mouth opening and facial pain over the past year. The patient's deteriorating condition was causing significant discomfort, affecting his daily activities, and leading to decreased quality of life.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reported experiencing pain in his jaw joint area on both sides, specifically in the pre-auricular regions. Additionally, he described masticatory myalgia that was more pronounced in his masseter muscles. He expressed difficulty while chewing food due to this prolonged stiffness and noted that it persisted for several hours after waking up in the morning. The discomfort seemed to worsen during functional movements involving the jaw joint.  Medical History: The patient had no history of trauma or infection involving the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). However, he did suffer from systemic sclerosis (SSc) since early adulthood, which primarily affected his skin but also involved some internal organs. SSc-related symptoms such as Raynaud's phenomenon and digital ulcers had been managed previously with vasodilators under rheumatology care.  Clinical Assessment: On examination, it was observed that the patient had limited mouth opening, reaching only 25 mm interincisally compared to a normal mouth opening range of approximately 40-50 mm. There were no evident signs of facial asymmetry or swelling overlying TMJ areas upon visual inspection.  Palpation revealed bilateral tenderness in pre-auricular areas below both zygomatic arches - an indication of TMJ involvement. Further palpation confirmed increased muscle tension and tenderness bilaterally along with trigger points found within masseter muscles during contraction.  Additional diagnostic tests were performed:  1. Radiographic Evaluation: Orthopantomogram (OPG) was conducted to rule out any bony abnormalities or osteoarthritic changes within the TMJ and surrounding structures. The radiograph showed no significant degenerative signs or condylar abnormalities, confirming that the patient's symptoms were more muscular in nature.  2. Imaging of TMJ: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) demonstrated joint disc displacement in both right and left TMJ with a reduction beyond the midsagittal plane during mouth opening movements. There were no other structural anomalies observed.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical assessment and diagnostic results, a diagnosis of temporomandibular joint dysfunction (TMD) was made for this patient. The likely cause of TMD was determined to be muscle hyperactivity within the masticatory muscles, particularly the masseter, leading to pain and restricted jaw movement.  Treatment Plan: Considering the severity of symptoms and functional limitations experienced by the patient, a multidisciplinary approach was recommended:  1. Pharmacological Management: The patient was prescribed a short course of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to help reduce inflammation and alleviate pain.   2. Physical Therapy: A referral for physical therapy sessions focusing on stretching exercises for jaw muscles along with moist heat applications over affected areas was arranged.  3. Occlusal Appliance Therapy: To provide additional support and relieve stress on his jaw joints, a custom-fit occlusal splint was fabricated for nighttime use.  4. Patient Education: The importance of maintaining good oral hygiene practices along with dietary modifications involving soft food consumption during acute episodes compounded by SSc symptoms were emphasized.  5. Follow-up Visits: Regular follow-up visits were planned to monitor progress, make necessary adjustments in treatment plans, and ensure optimal management of his condition.  Conclusion: This case highlights how temporomandibular joint dysfunction can manifest alongside systemic sclerosis in an adult male patient presenting with limited mouth opening and facial pain. Timely diagnosis, collaborative treatment, and patient education play key roles in managing TMD effectively, enabling the restoration of function and improvement in quality of life for patients.  Note: This is a fictitious clinical case study created for educational purposes. Any resemblance to actual patients or their medical conditions is purely coincidental.

We present here a case of a 1-month-old infant who presented with multiple facial injuries. The baby was previously in good health until his mother noticed unusual crying and blood on the right side of his face approximately 2 hours prior to arrival at our clinic. On closer examination, she observed complete loss of the right upper and lower eyelids, partial loss of the nostrils, and an ulcerated lesion on the right cheek. There were no witnesses to the incident that led to these injuries. According to the mother's recollection, about 1 hour before the incident occurred, she had breastfed her child and then placed him in a stroller near a table about 80cm from the ground.  The patient's name is Eric, a term-born male infant who has been healthy since birth. He was delivered via spontaneous vaginal delivery at full-term without any complications noted during or after birth. His Apgar scores were normal (9 at one minute and 10 at five minutes). Eric is currently being exclusively breastfed by his mother and gaining weight appropriately.  Upon examination, Eric appeared irritable and demonstrated signs of distress throughout our evaluation. We found significant facial deformities consistent with what was described by his mother earlier. Loss of both upper and lower eyelids on the right side resulted in exposure keratopathy as evidenced by decreased corneal reflexes upon stimulation with a cotton swab.  Further assessment revealed partial loss of tissue around both nostrils leading to noticeable asymmetry when compared to his left nostril. The ulcerated lesion on Eric's right cheek seemed deep but not actively bleeding at that moment.  Cerebral imaging studies including computed tomography (CT) scan were performed promptly due to concerns for possible underlying craniofacial abnormalities contributing to these severe injuries; however, they did not reveal any significant findings apart from localized soft tissue destruction involving only superficial layers.  Considering several plausible etiologies for these injuries, we engaged in a thorough discussion with Eric's mother to elicit any relevant historical information. She denied any incidents involving blunt force trauma or falls from a height. There was no suggestive history of household pets, chemical exposures, or previous contact with individuals affected by infectious diseases.  Given the significant clinical findings and absence of an apparent cause for the injuries, a multidisciplinary approach was adopted to provide comprehensive care for Eric. The involvement of specialists including pediatric surgery, plastic surgery, ophthalmology, and dermatology allowed us to create an individualized management plan based on his unique needs.  Treatment included sterile wound care using moist dressings and topical antibiotic ointment to promote healing and prevent infection. Eye lubricants were prescribed to combat dryness caused by loss of eyelid protection. Regular follow-up visits were scheduled to monitor his progress closely.  As part of the evaluation process encompassing child welfare concerns in these cases, our medical team arranged psycho-social supportive measures for Eric's family while actively involving appropriate child protection services who are essential stakeholders in safeguarding the well-being of all infants under their jurisdiction.  In conclusion, Eric presented with multiple facial injuries characterized by loss of upper and lower eyelids on one side along with partial tissue destruction involving nostrils and a cheek ulceration. Despite extensive evaluation including imaging studies ruling out underlying craniofacial abnormalities contributing to these injuries, no specific etiology could be identified at this stage. Close interdisciplinary collaboration has been instituted to optimize medical management while addressing potential psychosocial factors associated with this unusual presentation in early infancy.

A 65-year-old woman was admitted to our department in September 2021 with a complaint of a lump in her right breast. She reported noticing the lump three months prior, which had gradually increased in size. The patient denied any associated pain, nipple discharge, or changes in breast contour.  On physical examination, a firm, non-tender mass measuring approximately 4 cm was palpable in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There were no signs of skin changes, nipple retraction, or axillary lymphadenopathy. The contralateral breast appeared normal upon examination.  Given the worrisome findings on clinical examination, further investigations were warranted to determine the nature and extent of the mass. A mammogram and subsequent ultrasound were performed to evaluate the lesion further.  The mammogram revealed an irregular density suggestive of a solid mass with speculated margins within the right upper outer quadrant. The ultrasound confirmed the presence of an irregular hypoechoic nodule with posterior acoustic shadowing and microcalcifications suspicious for malignancy.  In light of these findings and considering age-appropriate guidelines for comprehensive evaluation, additional imaging studies were carried out to assess for locoregional as well as distant spread of disease while ruling out primary tumor involvement elsewhere.  A chest X-ray showed clear lung fields without any evidence of pulmonary nodules or infiltration. An abdominal ultrasound demonstrated no liver lesions or gallbladder pathology; furthermore, there were no pancreatic abnormalities noted during visualization using this modality. Normal spleen size and architecture were visualized along with unremarkable kidneys bilaterally without evidence of tumor infiltration or hydronephrosis. Lastly, ureteric peristalsis was normal along its course through both pelvicalyceal systems down to their junctions with urinary bladder that also appeared unremarkable during ultrasound assessment.  After obtaining informed consent from our patient highlighting potential benefits versus associated risks/complications from surgery like sample-taking diagnostic procedures, a core biopsy of the breast mass was performed. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of an invasive ductal carcinoma with corresponding grade 2/III associated microcalcifications.  Given the diagnosis of invasive carcinoma, pretreatment staging assessment was pursued to determine disease extent and guide subsequent management decisions. A bone scan revealed no evidence of skeletal metastasis or areas suggestive of increased metabolic activity in osseous structures.  In summary, a 65-year-old woman presented with a palpable lump in her right breast characterized by imaging studies as an irregular hypoechoic nodule suspicious for malignancy. Extensive imaging evaluation including abdominal ultrasound ruled out primary tumor involvement elsewhere. Core biopsy confirmed an invasive ductal carcinoma with associated microcalcifications. Subsequent bone scan excluded bony metastasis.  The patient's case was discussed at our multi-disciplinary tumor board meeting to develop an individualized treatment plan tailored to her specific needs and disease characteristics. Based on the tumor board's recommendations, the next step in our patient's management was to determine the estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) status of her breast cancer, as these factors played a crucial role in tailoring the therapeutic approach.  Immunohistochemistry testing revealed that the tumor cells were negative for both ER and PR expression. Further analysis using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) demonstrated amplification of HER2 gene signals, confirming HER2-positive status. These findings indicated that our patient's breast cancer showed aggressive features and would benefit from targeted therapy against HER2.  Considering this information, systemic staging investigations were performed to determine any distant metastasis. A whole-body positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) scan was conducted to assess distant organ involvement.  The PET-CT scan showed increased fluorodeoxyglucose uptake within multiple lymph nodes along the right axilla, suggesting locoregional lymphadenopathy consistent with nodal involvement. However, there were no signs of distant metastasis to other organs or structures observed on imaging studies.  The comprehensive staging results indicated stage IIIA breast cancer based on tumor size (>4 cm), clinical nodal involvement, and absence of distant metastasis. Taking into account this advanced stage at presentation and aggressive molecular profile of HER2-positive disease status with hormone receptor negativity, our patient qualified for neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery as per standard treatment guidelines.  After discussing all treatment options along with their potential benefits and risks, our patient consented for neoadjuvant chemotherapy aimed at downstaging her tumor before considering surgical intervention.  She was initiated on a combination regimen consisting of docetaxel and trastuzumab every three weeks for six cycles. Close monitoring was maintained throughout chemotherapy to evaluate treatment response using clinical examination combined with periodic imaging studies, including breast ultrasound and physical examination.  Following completion of neoadjuvant chemotherapy, restaging studies confirmed a significant reduction in the size of the primary tumor. The lump was no longer palpable on clinical examination. Moreover, imaging evaluation showed a decrease in axillary lymphadenopathy, suggesting excellent response to treatment.  Given this favorable response to chemotherapy, our patient subsequently underwent right-sided modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection. Pathological examination of the surgical specimen revealed an absence of residual invasive carcinoma within the breast tissue and no involvement of any resected lymph nodes.  Postoperatively, she was referred to radiation oncology for adjuvant radiotherapy to further reduce local recurrence risk at both chest wall and regional nodal basins based on clinical and pathological characteristics.  In conclusion, our 65-year-old female patient presented with a palpable lump in her right breast that was found to be an invasive ductal carcinoma upon histopathological examination. Extensive staging investigations ruled out distant metastasis while core biopsy profiling indicated HER2-positive disease with hormone receptor negativity. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy resulted in a significant tumor response allowing for curative surgical intervention followed by adjuvant radiotherapy as part of her comprehensive treatment plan moving forward.  The multidisciplinary team will continue monitoring her closely during regular follow-up visits to ensure appropriate surveillance and early detection of any potential recurrence or side effects related to previous treatments while providing ongoing support throughout her cancer journey.

Ms. ABC, a 58-year-old retired librarian, was referred to our unit for further evaluation and management of her recent gynecological symptoms. She presented with a history of irregular, painless vaginal bleeding that had been ongoing for the past six months. Upon referral, she had already undergone an endometrial biopsy at a secondary hospital.  Ms. ABC's medical history revealed that she reached menopause at the age of 49 and has been postmenopausal for the past nine years. She has been sexually inactive for the last ten years and denies any prior use of contraception or hormone replacement therapy. There is no known history of sexually transmitted infections.  Her first menstrual period started at age 13, and she never experienced any significant gynecological problems during her reproductive years. She has not previously undergone Pap smear cervical cytology testing.  On physical examination, Ms. ABC appeared well-nourished with no apparent signs of distress or discomfort. Her vital signs were within normal limits, including blood pressure (120/80 mmHg) and heart rate (70 beats per minute). A comprehensive gynecological examination revealed no palpable masses or tenderness upon gentle palpation of the lower abdomen.  The results from her recent endometrial biopsy indicated the presence of abnormal cells suggestive of cellular atypia but did not definitively confirm any specific diagnosis.  Given these findings and in adherence to clinical protocols to rule out potential malignancy, additional investigations were planned for Ms. ABC to determine the origin and extent of her symptoms.  A pelvic ultrasound was ordered to evaluate both the uterine cavity and adnexa in order to visualize any potential anomalies or suspicious lesions within these structures that may explain her ongoing vaginal bleeding.  Furthermore, laboratory investigations were initiated including a complete blood count (CBC), coagulation profile (prothrombin time & activated partial thromboplastin time), liver function tests (LFTs), and renal function tests (serum creatinine and electrolytes). These investigations aimed to assess the overall health status of Ms. ABC, as well as provide valuable information regarding her coagulation profile prior to considering any potential interventions or surgical procedures.  A consultation with a gynecologic oncologist was also arranged to further evaluate the biopsy results and ensure appropriate follow-up for Ms. ABC's case. The gynecologic oncology specialist would play a crucial role in discussing the management options with the patient, providing guidance on potential treatment regimens, and determining whether further tissue sampling or alternative diagnostic procedures are necessary.  In conclusion, Ms. ABC's presentation of irregular vaginal bleeding warrants a thorough investigation to identify any underlying causes. Her age, postmenopausal status, absence of sexual activity or prior cervical cytology testing necessitate careful consideration of various possible diagnoses ranging from benign conditions such as uterine polyps or hormone imbalances to potentially more serious pathologies like endometrial cancer. Further diagnostic workup will be critical in determining an accurate diagnosis and guiding appropriate management tailored specifically for Ms. ABC's condition. Following the initial investigations performed for Ms. ABC, the pelvic ultrasound revealed a thickened endometrial lining measuring 11mm, suggestive of endometrial hyperplasia. However, no visible masses or abnormal structures were observed within the uterine cavity or adnexa.  Based on these findings, an outpatient hysteroscopy and dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure were scheduled to obtain a more definitive diagnosis and provide therapeutic intervention as necessary. The D&C would allow for the collection of tissue samples from the inner lining of the uterus to further evaluate any cellular abnormalities.  Prior to proceeding with the D&C procedure, Ms. ABC underwent routine preoperative assessments including a detailed medical history review and thorough physical examination by an anesthesiologist to ensure she was fit for anesthesia administration.  During the hysteroscopy and subsequent D&C, our team visualized a small polypoid lesion originating from within the endometrial cavity. The lesion appeared suspicious upon visual inspection due to its irregular surface characteristics and slightly friable nature. Samples of this lesion were collected for histopathological analysis through biopsy forceps during hysteroscopic resection.  Postoperatively, Ms. ABC recovered well without any immediate complications. Analgesics were prescribed as needed for pain management in case she experienced any discomfort following the procedure.  The histopathology report confirmed that the polypoid lesion removed from Ms. ABC's endometrium was indeed an atypical complex hyperplasia with focal areas of cellular crowding suggestive of carcinoma in situ (CIS). This finding raised concern over possible underlying malignancy within her endometrium.  A multidisciplinary meeting involving gynecologic oncologists, pathologists specialized in uterine pathology interpretation, radiologists familiar with imaging findings related to gynecological malignancies, as well as members of our clinical team was held to discuss these results thoroughly and develop an appropriate management plan.  Given the presence of atypical complex hyperplasia with areas suspicious for CIS, a CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was scheduled to assess for any potential metastatic spread or lymph node involvement. This imaging modality would help determine the appropriate staging of Ms. ABC's condition.  To further refine the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of her disease within the uterus, an expert opinion was sought from a gynecological pathologist specializing in uterine neoplasms to review her pathology slides. The expert pathologist confirmed high-grade endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (HG-EIN) with focal areas suspicious for early-stage endometrial adenocarcinoma.  Ms. ABC was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with a gynecologic oncologist to discuss treatment options based on her comprehensive assessment results. As part of her management plan, surgical intervention in the form of total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (removal of uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries) along with lymphadenectomy would be considered to achieve optimal disease control depending on staging findings obtained from CT scan results.  In conclusion, Ms. ABC's diagnosis advanced from endometrial hyperplasia detected during initial investigations to high-grade endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (HG-EIN) suggestive of early-stage endometrial adenocarcinoma upon further evaluation. Collaborative efforts between various specialists including gynecologists, pathologists specialized in uterine neoplasms interpretation, radiologists familiar with gynecological malignancies imaging features were essential in guiding evidence-based decision-making regarding appropriate interventions based on staging information provided by imaging studies and pathology expertise obtained through biopsy analysis conducted during hysteroscopic resection procedures performed earlier on this case.

We present the case of a 35-year-old patient with a medical history of hypertension, obesity, and a family history of coronary artery disease in both parents. The patient was diagnosed with heart failure five years ago when he experienced shortness of breath and fatigue while doing minimal physical activities. Since then, he has been closely monitored by our cardiology team.  The patient's clinical presentation has been consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). Echocardiographic findings revealed significant left ventricular dilation (estimated at 60mm) along with reduced systolic function indicated by an ejection fraction of 35%.
